answer_html: \(\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}=2\) As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the derivative does not exist at 1.
answer_latex:
$\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}=2$ As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the
derivative does not exist at 1.
hints_html:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that \(f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}\)

Since the function is defined piecewise and the function is broken up at 1, we will need to use the left and right hand limits to evaluate the derivative.

Remember that

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1\end{aligned}\]

You will need a variant of this.
hints_latex:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
$f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$

Since the function is defined piecewise and the function is broken up at
1, we will need to use the left and right hand limits to evaluate the
derivative.
hints_raw:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
<math>
f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}
</math>
Since the function is defined piecewise and the function is broken up at 1, we will need to use the left and right hand limits to evaluate the derivative.
Remember that

:<math>
\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1
</math>

You will need a variant of this.
sols_html:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that \(f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}\)

Since the functions differ on either side of 1, we will want to use one sided limit to attempt to evaluate the limit. If the one sided limits are equal, then the derivative exists. Otherwise, the derivative does not exist. Firstly, notice that \(f(1) = 2(1)+1 = 3\). From the left, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1-3}{x-1}\\ &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-4}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)}}{x-1} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4(x-1)}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\ &= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \end{aligned}\]

Now, to evaluate the last limit, recall that \(\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1\) hence \(\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2} = 1\) and so, multiplying top and bottom by 4, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\ &= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot 4(x-1)^2} \\ &= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot (2x-2)^2} \\ &= 4 - \frac43 \left( \lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2}\right)^2 \\ &= 4 - \frac{4}{3} \\ &= \frac{8}{3}\end{aligned}\]

As for the other side, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x+1-3}{x-1}\\ &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x-2}{x-1} \\ &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the derivative does not exist at 1.
sols_latex:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
$f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$

Since the functions differ on either side of 1, we will want to use one
sided limit to attempt to evaluate the limit. If the one sided limits
are equal, then the derivative exists. Otherwise, the derivative does
not exist. Firstly, notice that $f(1) = 2(1)+1 = 3$. From the left, we
have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-4}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)}}{x-1} \\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4(x-1)}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} 
\end{align*}

Now, to evaluate the last limit, recall that
$\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1$ hence
$\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2} = 1$ and so, multiplying top and
bottom by 4, we have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot 4(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot (2x-2)^2} \\
&= 4 - \frac43 \left( \lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2}\right)^2 \\
&= 4 - \frac{4}{3} \\
&= \frac{8}{3}
\end{align*}

As for the other side, we have

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x+1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x-2}{x-1} \\
&=  2 
\end{align*}

As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the
derivative does not exist at 1.
sols_raw:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
<math>
f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}
</math>

Since the functions differ on either side of 1, we will want to use one sided limit to attempt to evaluate the limit. If the one sided limits are equal, then the derivative exists. Otherwise, the derivative does not exist. Firstly, notice that <math> f(1) = 2(1)+1 = 3 </math>. From the left, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-4}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)}}{x-1} \\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4(x-1)}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} 
\end{align}
</math>

Now, to evaluate the last limit, recall that <math> \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1 </math> hence <math> \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2} = 1 </math> and so, multiplying top and bottom by 4, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot 4(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot (2x-2)^2} \\
&= 4 - \frac43 \left( \lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2}\right)^2 \\
&= 4 - \frac{4}{3} \\
&= \frac{8}{3}
\end{align}
</math>

As for the other side, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x+1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x-2}{x-1} \\
&=  2 \\
\end{align}
</math>

As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the derivative does not exist at 1.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.
Let

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)= \begin{cases} 4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1, & \textrm{if} \; x<1, \\ 2x+1, & \textrm{if} \; x\geq 1. \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

Use the definition of the derivative to find \(f'\)(1) or show that \(f'\)(1) does not exist.
statement_raw:
'''''Full-Solution Problems.''' In questions 2-8, justify your answers and '''show all your work.''' Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.''
<br />
Let

:<math>
f(x)= \begin{cases}
4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1, & \textrm{if} \; x<1, \\
2x+1, & \textrm{if} \; x\geq 1.
\end{cases}
</math>

Use the definition of the derivative to find ''&fnof;’(1)'' or show that ''&fnof;’(1)'' does not exist.
